questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated directly or indirectly by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate limiting enzyme of Glycogenolysis and has two forms: Active form ‘a’ and inactive form ‘b’. Phosphorylation of b can change it to active form a. Enzymes of glycogenolysis as any other catabolic pathway are activated in their phosphorylated state. So, any compound which cause phosphorylation will activate this enzyme and vice versa. However, Calcium in association with calmodulin (Ca-calmodulin) directly activates glycogen phosphorylase. For other options refer to figure below.

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of?
questions.correct_answer: D. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase. It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Enzyme defect Disease Body odor Phenylalanine hydroxylase Phenylketonuria Mousy/Musty Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase Isovaleric acidemia Rancid/cheesy/Sweaty feet Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase Tyrosinemia Type I boiled cabbage/rotten mushrooms. Tyrosine transaminase Tyrosinemia Type II PHPP hydroxylase (Complete Def) Tyrosinemia Type III PHPP hydroxylase (partial Def) Hawkinsinuria Swimming pool like

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Utilizes ribose Complete reaction of HMP HMP produces NADPH in oxidative phase. At the end of oxidative phase ribulose 5-P is produced which is further utilized for ribose 5-P synthesis (see fig) (so option D is false). Glyceraldehyde 3-P (one of the end-product of HMP) can enter into glycolysis to first form pyruvate and later acetyl CoA.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tangier’s disease Large orange/ yellow tonsils are a characteristic feature of Tangier’s disease. Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig). So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL ↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia). Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing: Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition) The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals . It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenylalanine at 508 Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine This protein helps in movement of H 2 O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva. In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of?

options.label: A
options.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: B
options.text: alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: C
options.text: Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.correct_answer: B. alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways: No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase. Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are: α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA) Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA) Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peroxisomes In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: SARS CoV-2 diagnosis is done by all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Southern blotting SARS CoV-2 is a ssRNA virus. So, detection of this virus involves detection of RNA which can be done by RT PCR and real time PCR both of which uses reverse transcriptase enzyme for synthesis of DNA from RNA and then normal PCR to quantify it. The second method which is used is based on detection of viral antigen which can be done using immunoassays. Southern blotting detects DNA which can’t be used for detection of this virus directly.

questions.text: Selenocysteine is present in which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutathione peroxidase Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are: Glutathione Peroxidase Thioredoxin Reductase Iodothyronine deiodinase Codon for selenocysteine: UGA This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains

options.label: C
options.text: Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.correct_answer: C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production. So, options with ATP (options a and b) can be excluded. 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large negative charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation (option d is wrong) and helps in deoxygenation. When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text: identify the left curve, given the fact that the right curve is of adult hemoglobin.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myoglobin The left curve is for myoglobin as it is a rectangular hyperbola curve which is characteristic of Michaelis Menton kinetics. Fetal hemoglobin, CO poisoning and acidosis will shift the sigmoidal shape of hemoglobin saturation curve as shown in the image below:

questions.text: True about sirtuins are all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: it is a histone deacetylase and it causes chromatin condensation

questions.correct_answer: A. Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism SIRTUINS : Silent Mating Type Information Regulatory Proteins. These proteins help in delaying the aging process as they are part of DNA base excision repair (option c is true) They improve glucose metabolism by increasing insulin sensitivity (option a is true) They have histone deacetylase activity. This activity will give rise to positive charge on histones resulting in its tight binding to DNA due to charge-charge interaction leading to chromatin condensation (option b is true) These proteins also have ADP ribosylation activity which require substrate NAD that gets converted to niacinamide (see fig below). So, the product niacinamide will inhibit the enzymatic activity of these proteins (option d is fasle).

questions.correct_answer: A. 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

questions.text: Fructosamine (which is used for assessing long term glycemic control in a person with hemolysis) is a glycated product of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Albumin Glucose can be attached to proteins, albumin, and also to RBCs forming HbA1c. Fructosamine is term used for all the glycated proteins including glycated albumin. (see figures below) In hemolysis patient, HbA1c analysis cannot be done because it will be falsely decreased due to damage to RBCs and loss of hemoglobin. So, fructosamine determination is used for these patients. Falsely high values Iron Deficiency Some anemias Hemoglobinopathies Falsely low values Hemolysis Reticulocytosis Hemoglobinopathies post hemorrhage or post transfusion

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Muscle and adipose tissues GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake. For other options refer to table below: Name Tissue Location Function GLUT-1 Brain, RBC, Placenta, Kidneys Basal Glucose Uptake GLUT-2 Liver, Pancreas, Intestine, Kidneys Intestine- Glucose absorption Liver- Glycogen formation Pancreas- Insulin release GLUT-3 Brain (Neuronal), Placenta, Kidneys Basal Glucose Uptake GLUT-4 Skeletal muscles, Cardiac muscles, Adipose tissues Insulin stimulated Glucose uptake after meals GLUT-5 Small intestine, Testis (Sperms) Fructose transport

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to which of the following alcohols?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methyl alcohol Country liquor can be categorised as spurious liquor or hooch when the amount of methane added could turn fatal. There are number of death cases reported every year due to consumption of such alcohol. The metabolism of methyl alcohol is shown in figure below: The formaldehyde and formic acid formed as products during the metabolism can cause severe metabolic acidosis, blindness and neurologic damage. The treatment involves administration of ethanol or Fomepizole which act as competitive inhibitors of enzyme ADH and prevent the formation of these two products.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: To break AT bonds high Tm is required

options.label: B
options.text: To break GC bonds low Tm is required

options.label: C
options.text: To break AT bonds low Tm is required

options.label: D
options.text: AT bonds and GC bonds need the same TM

questions.correct_answer: C. To break AT bonds low Tm is required
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To break AT bonds low Tm is required In DNA, there are two hydrogen bonds between A and T and three hydrogen bonds between G and C. So, AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds as less energy is required for breaking 2 bonds compared to three bonds.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non competitive The above graph shows that in the presence of inhibitor, the Km remains the same whereas Vmax is decreased, which is the case in Non-competitive inhibition. Refer to table for other inhibitors: Summary of effect of different Inhibitors Type of Inhibition K m V ma x Competitive Inhibitors Non-competitive Inhibitors Uncompetitive Inhibitors Increased Same decreased Same decreased decreased

questions.text: Assertion: PKU is characterised by mousy odour Reason: Tyrosine and norepinephrine are not found in PKU

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true but reason is false

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is false but Reason is true.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion In PKU there is musty odour due to the formation of phenylketones. So, assertion in itself is true but the reason given is not the correct explanation of assertion. In PKU, as the phenylalanine to tyrosine conversion is inhibited, and tyrosine is also required for formation of NE, so both will not be formed. So, reason is a correct statement.

questions.text: Identify the given image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gaucher’s disease The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells (see images below) which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase.
